By EMIL PAVLOVIC§
Hopkins, according to a recent
compilation by the New York
Times, now has the fourth highest
paid university faculty in the United States, exceeded only by Harvard, MIT, and Cal Tech.
Hopkins, as recently as 1956,
was mired at the "B" level for faculty compensation on the scale of
the American Association of University Professors (AAUP). That
organization sets certain ranges of
salaries, which it then rates alphabetically, "AA" being the highest
and most desirable and the others
trailing off into various lesser degrees of desirability.
Milton Eisenhower, when he
became University president in
1956, established as one of his
prime objectives increases in faculty salaries to a level at which
they would compete with any'
school in the country . With the
implementation of his pledge of
increases, the average faculty salary at Hopkins has now nearly
doubled from its 1956 level.

Hopkins biologist John J. Cebra was presented with the Eli Lilly

honors.

antibody systems.

University of Pennsylvania, and his Ph. D. from Rockefeller University. He came to Hopkins as an Associate Professor of Biology, last
year.

Dr. Helene B. Taussig, pediatrician at the Hopkins Hospital, has
praised the Hospital because it has
not, as yet, performed the muchpublicized heart transplants on humans.
Dr. Taussig is responsible for
deciding which operations on infants will be performed at the Hospital. She believes that heart transplants are still in the research stage
and that Hopkins' reluctance to
perform these operations at this
time will set a good example for
other hospitals. J. H. H. feels that
the new operation is overly hazardous at this point.
Hopkins had previously followed a similar proeedure regarding
open heart surgery. This policy
was valuable in discouraging other
hospitals from performing these
dangerous operations until the
techniques were fully developed.
Capable for Years
Dr. J. Alexander Haller, pediatric surgeon at the Hospital stated
that Hopkins has been capable of
performing the technical aspects of
heart transplants for the last five
years. It was delayed, however,
due to the problems in controlling
the rejection of the foreign heart.
The drugs available today which
will suppress rejection of the alien
organ, also block antibody formation in general, leaving the patient
acutely susceptible to bacterial infection. Dr. Haller sees a possible
answer in a new substance called
antilymphocyte serum. This is an
antibody isolated from a horse injected with human lymphocytes.
The scrum, injected into a human, would specificly attack the
lymphocytes which are responsible
for rejecting transplanted hearts.
It would leave the other types of
white blood cells free to combat
general infection.

Dr. Haller indicated that the
first heart transplants at Hopkins
would probably be performed on
children with congenital heart abnormalities or adults with diseased
coronary arteries. These malfunctions can not be corrected in any
other way. Malfunctioning valves,
on the other hand, can be efficiently replaced by artificial valves,
thus eliminating the need for heart
transplants in this specific case.
Dr. Haller added that before
heart transplants should be performed on humans, kidney transplants should be performed. In the
latter case, if the operation fails
the patient can be plugged into an

artificial kidney and will not die.
It seems that a general principle
in surgery is,"do no harm." Many
surgeons believe that if one performs a heart transplant on a patient and then gives him a drug
which allows him to die, one is irm
plicating oneself in the patient's
death.
The general feeling at Hopkins
Hospital is that the ultimate answer will probably be artificial
hearts(in lieu of hearts transplanted from other humans). This will
eliminate the thorny problem of
storage, and enable the surgeon to
take an artificial heart off the shelf
whenever needed.

Dr. Helene B. Taussig, pediatrician at the Hopkins Hospital, has
praised the Hospital because it has
not, as yet, performed the muchpublicized heart transplants on humans.
Dr. Taussig is responsible for
deciding which operations on infants will be performed at the Hospital. She believes that heart transplants are still in the research stage
and that Hopkins' reluctance to
perform these operations at this
time will set a good example for
other hospitals. J. H. H. feels that
the new operation is overly hazardous at this point.
Hopkins had previously followed a similar proeedure regarding
open heart surgery. This policy
was valuable in discouraging other
hospitals from performing these
dangerous operations until the
techniques were fully developed.
Capable for Years
Dr. J. Alexander Haller, pediatric surgeon at the Hospital stated
that Hopkins has been capable of
performing the technical aspects of
heart transplants for the last five
years. It was delayed, however,
due to the problems in controlling
the rejection of the foreign heart.
The drugs available today which
will suppress rejection of the alien
organ, also block antibody formation in general, leaving the patient
acutely susceptible to bacterial infection. Dr. Haller sees a possible
answer in a new substance called
antilymphocyte serum. This is an
antibody isolated from a horse injected with human lymphocytes.
The scrum, injected into a human, would specificly attack the
lymphocytes which are responsible
for rejecting transplanted hearts.
It would leave the other types of
white blood cells free to combat
general infection.

Dr. Haller indicated that the
first heart transplants at Hopkins
would probably be performed on
children with congenital heart abnormalities or adults with diseased
coronary arteries. These malfunctions can not be corrected in any
other way. Malfunctioning valves,
on the other hand, can be efficiently replaced by artificial valves,
thus eliminating the need for heart
transplants in this specific case.
Dr. Haller added that before
heart transplants should be performed on humans, kidney transplants should be performed. In the
latter case, if the operation fails
the patient can be plugged into an

artificial kidney and will not die.
It seems that a general principle
in surgery is,"do no harm." Many
surgeons believe that if one performs a heart transplant on a patient and then gives him a drug
which allows him to die, one is irm
plicating oneself in the patient's
death.
The general feeling at Hopkins
Hospital is that the ultimate answer will probably be artificial
hearts(in lieu of hearts transplanted from other humans). This will
eliminate the thorny problem of
storage, and enable the surgeon to
take an artificial heart off the shelf
whenever needed.
